author: By Melissa S. Kearney
title: The Explosive Rise of Single-Parent Families Is Not a Good Thing
description: How the erosion of the convention of raising children inside a two-parent home is damaging families and worsening economic inequality.
content: There has been a huge transformation in the way children are raised in the United States: the erosion of the convention of raising children inside a two-parent home. This shift is often not publicly challenged or lamented, in an effort to be inclusive of a diversity of family arrangements. But this well-meaning acceptance obscures the critical reality that this change is hurting our children and our society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Klemm and Isabella Winkler
title: Is the Disaster in Libya Coming Soon to an Aging Dam Near You?
description: Aging dams are a threat around the world. Our best tool is removing them altogether.
content: The collapse of two dams in Libya, unleashing torrential floodwaters that left at least 3,000 people dead and over 4,200 still missing, was both predicted and preventable. And they won’t be the last big dams to collapse unless we remove and repair some of the aging and obsolete structures that are long past their expiration date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jules Melancon, Oyster Farmer Who Tried Something New, Dies at 65
description: In the wake of hurricanes and the BP oil spill, he revolutionized his industry by turning from wild catches to cage farming his precious bivalves.
content: Jules Melancon, a third-generation Louisiana oysterman who, rather than giving up after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill ravaged the Gulf Coast, found an innovative, sustainable and much tastier way to bring his briny delicacies to New Orleans restaurants, died on Aug. 31 at his home in Cut Off, La. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Daniel Berehulak
title: In Ukraine, a Rosh Hashana Party Not Even War Can Stop
description: Every year, thousands of followers of Rebbe Nachman of Breslov descend on the town of Uman to worship, dance and pay homage at the tomb of their spiritual leader.
content: Yosef Chaim Bernfeld, a young businessman from New York who is trying to straighten out his life, journeyed to Uman this weekend for a “spiritual fix.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Wildenstein Art Dynasty Faces a Tax Trial in France — Again
description: Guy Wildenstein, the billionaire art dealer, is accused of shielding a prized art collection from tax authorities to avoid a hefty inheritance bill. The case has dogged his family for more than a decade.
content: Guy Wildenstein, the international art dealer, is scheduled to return to court in Paris this week to face accusations of massive tax fraud and money laundering in a lengthy legal battle that has slowly chipped away at the prestige and secrecy of a family dynasty that once dominated the global art market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: ‘A Terrible Mistake’: Trump Criticizes DeSantis on Abortion Ban
description: The former president, while denouncing his chief rival for the Republican nomination, also largely evaded questions on the issue.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, whose Supreme Court appointments led to the overturning of Roe v. Wade, harshly criticized his top rival in the Republican presidential primary, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, for a six-week abortion ban that he called a “terrible thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Cassandra Vinograd and Vivek Shankar
title: Ukraine Says It Has Retaken Strategic Village Near Bakhmut
description: The small village of Klishchiivka is the second settlement in eastern Ukraine that Kyiv’s forces say they have retaken in three days.
content: Ukraine’s military said Sunday it had retaken the small village of Klishchiivka, the second settlement to come back under Kyiv’s control in three days and the most significant recent advance in its hard-fought counteroffensive to drive Russian forces from the country’s east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Balanchine’s Gems Were His Dancers. He Honored Them With ‘Jewels.’
description: Original cast members talk about their experiences making the three-part plotless ballet, which opens New York City Ballet’s 75th anniversary season.
content: The sylvan glade romanticism of “Emeralds,” the electric energy of “Rubies,” the glittering imperial court of “Diamonds.” These are the three parts of George Balanchine’s “Jewels,” from 1967, often described as the first full-length plotless ballet. On Tuesday, New York City Ballet will open its 75th anniversary season with “Jewels,” and a tribute to all the dancers who make up the company’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: The Man Who Wrote Everything
description: In “Bartleby and Me,” Gay Talese recalls ink-stained colleagues, shares trade secrets and digs through the ruins of a truly explosive Manhattan marriage.
content: Gay Talese has a tic. I want to get this out of the way because in general I have such tremendous admiration for the man: that debonair eminence of ye olde New Journalism who is both a living landmark of Manhattan and his own best character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Lauren Petracca
title: Why a Landfill as Tall as the Statue of Liberty May Rise Even Higher
description: A plan for Seneca Meadows would fill a “valley” with enough trash to fill MetLife Stadium 10 times, at least.
content: It’s tough to miss Seneca Meadows, New York state’s largest landfill: Rising nearly 300 feet tall, it’s almost as tall as the Statue of Liberty, including its pedestal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: A Remote Road Trip
description: Adventure tourism in places like Mongolia is becoming more popular.
content: In 2001, a British man named Tom Morgan decided to host an extreme car race. It would start in Britain and end in what he thought was the world’s most difficult destination for most people to reach: Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, more than 5,500 miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
title: Top Democrats’ Bullishness on Biden 2024 Collides With Voters’ Worries
description: Party leaders have rallied behind the president’s re-election bid, but as one top Democratic strategist put it, “The voters don’t want this, and that’s in poll after poll after poll.”
content: As President Biden shifts his re-election campaign into higher gear, the strength of his candidacy is being tested by a striking divide between Democratic leaders, who are overwhelmingly unified behind his bid, and rank-and-file voters in the party who harbor persistent doubts about whether he is their best option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francis Sanzaro
title: When I Stopped Trying to Self-Optimize, I Got Better
description: The growth mind-set. The abundance mind-set. The gratitude mind-set. I threw them all away.
content: A few years ago, I stood underneath a red overhanging cliff near my hometown, Carbondale, Colo. The day was a stunner. Elk chewed on the brown grasses by the river below. A hawk rode the wind. Townsfolk and itinerants, some clothed and some not, loitered in a nearby hot spring. I was tied in, ready to climb. I was attempting to do a route first try, “onsight,” as we call it, which means I didn’t know what I was climbing into. It would have been a hard onsight for me — to onsight hard climbs, you need clarity. No interference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Turner
title: They’re Ultrarich Techies, and They Want to Build a City From Scratch. What Could Go Wrong?
description: The latest effort by tech titans to create their own “technotopia” doesn’t bode well for cities old or new.
content: Tech leaders are fed up with cities and their politics. So they want to start over. And that doesn’t bode well for cities old or new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: How a Yale Student’s Rape Accusation Exposed Her to a Defamation Lawsuit
description: The woman’s allegation led to the expulsion of Saifullah Khan, who was acquitted in a criminal trial. His lawsuit is now challenging these disciplinary hearings.
content: In a 2018 disciplinary hearing at Yale University, Saifullah Khan listened as a woman accused him of raping her after a Halloween party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Anna Netrebko Returns to Berlin, Amid Protests and Some Boos
description: The Russian star soprano appeared in her first staged opera in Germany since the Ukraine invasion, still under fire for her past support for President Vladimir V. Putin.
content: The Berlin State Opera’s production of Verdi’s “Macbeth” begins with the madly ambitious Lady Macbeth slowly walking over a burning battlefield, carrying a sword as she negotiates a stage littered with corpses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Most Interesting Element of the Hunter Biden Indictment
description: An otherwise ordinary case involving the president’s son lands at a moment of constitutional chaos regarding firearm regulations.
content: In one sense, the Hunter Biden indictment just isn’t that remarkable, or interesting. Aside from the fact that it’s brought against the president’s son, it’s just plain vanilla gun charges, and the prosecution seems to have him dead to rights. He lied on Form 4473 — the federal form he was required to fill out when he purchased the weapon in question — by certifying that he was not illegally using drugs. He has since publicly stated that he was regularly using drugs, including crack cocaine, when he bought the gun. Thus, there’s overwhelming evidence he committed two related crimes, lying on the form and possessing the weapon itself. Federal law prohibits unlawful users of controlled substances from possessing firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Was on Just Such a Cool Day That I Set Out From the Upper West Side’
description: A walk across town, learning to roller skate in Harlem and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Watts
title: For America’s ‘Wild Girls,’ the Natural World Meant Freedom
description: In her new book, the historian Tiya Miles shows how formative outdoor experiences helped diverse women — from Harriet Tubman to Indigenous athletes — transcend prescribed social and gender roles.
content: Tiya Miles’s “Wild Girls” is a thoroughly absorbing exploration of the formative role that nature has played in American women’s lives. A beautiful synthesis of diverse women’s experiences, combining history with memoir and a call to action, this brisk, elegant study — the first in a new series of “short” nonfiction books from Norton — demonstrates how the natural world functioned as a girlhood training ground for adult resistance to the country’s confining gender roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Behind Paxton’s Impeachment, a Republican Battle for Control of Texas
description: The impeachment was the latest fight in an ongoing struggle between an emboldened hard right and the party’s more moderate old guard.
content: The impeachment trial of Ken Paxton that ended in his acquittal on Saturday was about more than the fate of the Texas attorney general. It was also the most dramatic flashpoint in a yearslong struggle among Republican leaders in the Legislature over control of the party and the future direction of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts, Vik Jolly and Orlando Mayorquin
title: After Fatal Shooting of L.A. County Deputy, an Outpouring of Grief
description: The officer was found unconscious in his patrol car in Palmdale, a city near Los Angeles. It was unclear whether there was more than one suspect or what the motive was.
content: Investigators searched for clues on Sunday following the ambush-style killing of a Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputy, as outpourings of grief flowed over the officer’s dedication to public service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Martin
title: Nathan Hill’s ‘Wellness’ Satirizes the Modern Condition — Kind Of
description: The second novel by the author of “The Nix” follows a young Chicago couple’s trajectory from pre-internet optimism to 21st-century ennui.
content: Nathan Hill’s novels are, among other things, feats of narrative architecture. “My projects are vast creatures of shocking complexity,” a real-estate developer none-too-humbly notes early in Hill’s new novel, “Wellness” — “intricate, unruly, asynchronous, a little baroque.” Given the vastness of the 600-page book that follows, one can’t help imagining the author is supplying a would-be ars poetica of his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: House G.O.P. Considers Stopgap Spending Bill to Avert a Shutdown
description: Republicans were presented a plan on Sunday night to cut spending, impose strict border restrictions and keep federal agencies open for another month to allow more time to pass annual spending bills.
content: House Republicans considered a new stopgap funding proposal on Sunday aimed at averting a government shutdown at the end of the month, but it was unlikely that the plan, which would slash spending for most federal agencies and resurrect tough Trump-era border initiatives, could break the deep impasse on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: New White House Counsel’s To-Do List: Impeachment on Day 2
description: A veteran of the Obama White House, Ed Siskel had one day to settle in before Speaker Kevin McCarthy opened an impeachment inquiry into President Biden.
content: Ed Siskel moved from Chicago to Washington last weekend to begin his new role as White House counsel. He had one entire day — last Monday — to settle into his office, in a coveted corner on the second floor of the West Wing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Facing Pushback From Both Parties, New Mexico Governor Scales Back Firearms Order
description: The initial order had prohibited the carrying of firearms in public areas or on state property. Criticism swiftly followed, and the governor limited the ban to parks and playgrounds.
content: Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham of New Mexico on Friday scaled back a temporary public health order restricting the carrying of firearms in the Albuquerque metro area, limiting a ban to only parks and playgrounds. The initial ban, which was issued Sept. 8 and was to have covered 30 days, had prohibited the carrying of open and concealed firearms in public areas or on state property.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Little Progress in Talks to End Strike Against 3 Detroit Automakers
description: The U.A.W. returned to the bargaining table on Sunday after its president warned, “We’re going to amp this thing up” if the car companies don’t improve their offers.
content: The United Auto Workers and the big three Detroit automakers largely held their ground on Sunday, seemingly no closer to reaching deals than they were when the autoworkers went on strike on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘Heart of Brick’ Review: A Homebody Goes Clubbing, and Tells All
description: The production, about the slow rewards of romance, starring the musician serpentwithfeet, premiered at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan on Friday.
content: “My vibe is cozy, comfortable,” the R&B musician Josiah Wise, professionally known as serpentwithfeet, says near the start of “Heart of Brick.” Covered in a fuzzy blanket, sipping a glass of wine, he tells us that he prefers to stay at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. and Chinese Officials Meet in Malta to Discuss Ukraine and Other Flashpoints
description: The talks between Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser, and Wang Yi, China’s top diplomat, took place as the two governments are trying to set up a Biden-Xi meeting.
content: The White House announced on Sunday that its national security adviser met over the weekend with China’s top diplomat in Malta, as part of efforts to keep communication open between the two nations and as political purges roil elite circles in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: In Reversal, Drew Barrymore Pauses Show’s Return Until End of Strike
description: Taping began on her talk show last week, but at the 11th hour Barrymore changed course, and at least two other daytime programs followed.
content: After an onslaught of criticism over her decision to return her show to the air while Hollywood is on strike, Drew Barrymore reversed herself on Sunday and at least two other shows did the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Maybe They’re Losing Because They All Sound the Same
description: The claustrophobic reality of Ron DeSantis and the other Republicans is that they constructed their identities as Trump alternatives and ended up all the same.
content: There’s a late-summer-fade quality to the Republican primary contest, as if the candidates are passively sliding into the inevitability of a Biden-Trump rematch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: California Governor to Sign Landmark Climate Disclosure Bill
description: The first-in-the-nation law will compel major companies to publicly disclose their carbon dioxide emissions and could have national repercussions.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said on Sunday that he would sign a landmark climate bill that passed the state’s legislature last week requiring major companies to publicly disclose their greenhouse gas emissions, a move with national and global repercussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown and Marlena Sloss
title: ‘Run With Joy and Love’
description: Markelle Taylor started running as part of the 1000 Mile Club in San Quentin State Prison. Now he’s returning as a mentor.
content: On a glorious evening recently, the runner Markelle Taylor — otherwise known as “Markelle the Gazelle”— entered the dark sally port and crenelated towers of a place he was once overjoyed to leave behind: San Quentin State Prison. Accompanied by volunteer coaches from the prison’s 1000 Mile Club, Taylor, who was incarcerated for 18 years for second-degree murder, couldn’t wait to see his brothers, lifers all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: 2 Charged With Murder in Day Care Death of 1-Year-Old
description: The owner of the day care center and her tenant were charged in the death of Nicholas Dominici, who the authorities said had been exposed to fentanyl.
content: A day care center operator and her tenant were charged with murder in the death of a 1-year-old boy who had just started at the center and was exposed to fentanyl there, the police and his family said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Harmlessly Deceive
description: Kevin Christian and Andrea Carla Michaels set the tone for a good week.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Painful Past Behind South Korean Adoptions
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 17, 2023.
content: “It’s like human trafficking. If this happened to me, how many others did they do this to?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Russell Brand Denies Accusations of ‘Egregious’ Sexual Assaults
description: Three British media outlets published an investigation in which four women accused him of sexual assault in a series of incidents between 2006 and 2013.
content: The comedian Russell Brand denied “serious criminal allegations” against him in a video he posted shortly before three British news organizations published an investigation Saturday in which four women accused him of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Jets Return to Zach Wilson With Familiar Result
description: Under pressure from the Cowboys’ stellar defense, the Jets had four giveaways, including three interceptions thrown by Wilson, in the first game since Aaron Rodgers’s injury.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — The Dallas Cowboys throttled the Jets, 30-10, on Sunday afternoon, reminding the visitors from New York — as if any reminders were needed — of what the rest of their season may look like without quarterback Aaron Rodgers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 17, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 17, 2023.
content: An article on Page 20 this weekend about musicals, plays and festivals happening in the fall and spring misstates the month when “Days of Wine and Roses” is scheduled to begin performances on Broadway. It is January, not February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Tropical Storm Nigel Likely to Become a Hurricane on Sunday Night
description: The storm formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Saturday and continued to strengthen through the following day.
content: Hours after the powerful storm known as Lee made landfall in Canada, knocking out power for thousands, Tropical Storm Nigel formed in the Atlantic Ocean late on Saturday, becoming the latest named storm of the 2023 hurricane season. The storm continued to strengthen on Sunday, and was expected to become a hurricane during the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Margulies
title: The Stoic in the Bedroom
description: Learning to sleep under the stern gaze of Marcus Aurelius.
content: “Absolutely not,” I told my husband from the bed as he tried to find the right place on his dresser for Marcus Aurelius Antoninus. “I don’t need him staring at me all night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Corbett, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Zachary Mouton
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Inheritance Case That Could Unravel an Art Dynasty’
description: How a widow’s legal fight against the Wildenstein family of France has threatened its storied collection — and revealed the underbelly of the global art market.
content: Twenty years ago, a glamorous platinum-blond widow arrived at the Paris law office of Claude Dumont Beghi in tears. Someone was trying to take her horses — her “babies” — away, and she needed a lawyer to stop them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Joy (and Friendly Jostling) of Jollof Rice
description: However you make it, this West African dish of rice, tomatoes, lots of peppers and lots of spice is an excellent centerpiece for Sunday dinner.
content: Jollof rice is a West African dish made with rice, tomatoes, onions, lots of peppers and lots of spice. Nigerians prepare it differently from Ghanaians, who make it differently from Liberians. There are versions from Senegal, Cameroon and Sierra Leone. The debate over which is superior is always passionate, sometimes deadly serious. Each one is the best and only jollof rice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Helping America’s Struggling Students
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about addressing learning loss. Also: A warning about democracy; assault and rage; Senator Tommy Tuberville.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Elizabeth Paton
title: This China Trade War Isn’t About Semiconductors
description: Cosmetics sales in China are soaring, but a group of exporting nations led by France are pushing Beijing to lift restrictions they say are blocking them unfairly.
content: In the gloom of China’s economy, one area of business is booming: cosmetics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: World’s Largest ‘Baby Exporter’ Confronts Its Painful Past
description: South Korean adoptees have been returning to the country to hold the government accountable for what they call a corrupt adoption system that went largely unchanged until recent decades.
content: Mia Lee Sorensen’s Danish parents used to tell her that her birth family in South Korea had put her up for adoption. According to her adoption papers, she was born prematurely in 1987 to a family that could not afford her medical bills and wished for her to have a “good future” abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: China and the U.S. Vie for Secrets
description: Plus, confronting the world’s largest “baby exporter.”
content: The spy game between the U.S. and China is even more expansive than the one that played out between the Americans and the Soviets during the Cold War, said Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director. China’s large population and economy enable it to build intelligence services that are bigger than those of the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 18, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Desk Fit for a Founder
description: The pine and oak desk of Henry Jarvis Raymond, who founded The Times in 1851, has enjoyed pride of place in the newspaper’s headquarters for at least a century.
content: Introducing the first New-York Daily Times on Sept. 18, 1851, Henry Jarvis Raymond (1820-1869) promised readers that his newspaper would be issued every morning “for an indefinite number of years to come.” It’s been 172, so far. (The “Daily” was dropped in 1857 and the hyphen in 1896.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Live With Kelly and Mark’: Till Death (or Cancellation) Do They Part
description: As co-hosts, Kelly Ripa and Mark Consuelos are tasked with enacting a version of their marriage on-camera. Where does that performance begin and end?
content: At the start of the Feb. 16 episode of the ABC morning talk show “Live With Kelly and Ryan,” before the actress Camryn Manheim demonstrated her knowledge of American Sign Language, before Ryan Seacrest and the show’s resident D.J. competed in a game called “Love Songs,” the show’s host Kelly Ripa made an announcement: Seacrest, who had hosted with her for six years, would soon be departing. His replacement? “My husband, Mark Consuelos, in what Ryan and I are calling the nation’s weirdest social experiment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: How Coco Gauff Embodies the Biggest Story in Sports
description: As our Sports of The Times columnist moves to a new assignment, he reflects on a recurring theme from his tenure: the rise of female athletes.
content: What perfect timing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Says He Hopes Meadows Will Remain ‘Loyal’ to Him in Election Case
description: The former president, who has been warned against saying anything that could influence witnesses in his election interference case, made the statements during an interview on “Meet the Press.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said he hoped Mark Meadows — his final White House chief of staff and a co-defendant in a sweeping racketeering indictment in Georgia stemming from efforts to thwart the 2020 election — was still “loyal” to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Relief Efforts in Libya Turn to Disease Prevention, as Hopes for Finding Survivors Dim
description: Thousands were killed after dams broke last week in the country’s northeast, displacing more than 40,000 people, and leaving survivors with a shortage of medical supplies and drinking water.
content: Nearly a week after a powerful storm caused catastrophic flooding in northeastern Libya, rescue groups assessing the damage left behind after two dams collapsed in the city of Derna — washing entire neighborhoods out to sea — said that the death toll was still being assessed amid diminishing hopes for finding survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Janfaza
title: Doc Martens, Bomber Jackets, No Ties: Parsing Gen Z Politicians’ Style
description: Many of the country’s youngest elected officials hope to express authenticity through their clothing choices.
content: Wearing a dark green suit from Express and Cole Haan dress sneakers, Representative Maxwell Frost, Democrat of Florida, took the stage at Metrobar in Washington. He was speaking at an event this summer by Run for Something, a political action committee that supports young Democrats seeking state and local office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: How Germany’s Extreme Right Seized on the Martial Arts Scene
description: To increase their ranks, neo-Nazi groups in Germany and across Europe are using the sport as a training and recruiting tool.
content: A professional mixed martial arts fighter based in Berlin, Niko Samsonidse, has added a ritual to his tournament prep in recent years: vetting the event to ensure it is not organized by far-right extremists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Provenance of a Museum’s Greek Exhibit Is Questioned, Fueling a Debate
description: After a touring exhibition of antiquities from the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, Fla., raised concerns at a Denver museum, a curator was dismissed.
content: The Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, Fla., was riding high as “From Chaos to Order,” an exhibition of ancient Greek art, became its first major traveling show in years, making stops at museums in Florida and South Carolina before preparing to head west.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta, Hilary Howard and Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Climate Protesters March on New York, Calling for End to Fossil Fuels
description: Ahead of U.N. meetings this week, thousands gathered in Midtown to demand that President Biden and other world leaders stop new oil and gas drilling.
content: Tens of thousands of people, young and old, filled the streets of Midtown Manhattan under blazing sunshine on Sunday to demand that world leaders quickly pivot away from fossil fuels dangerously heating the Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
title: In Risky Hunt for Secrets, U.S. and China Expand Global Spy Operations
description: The nations are taking bold steps in the espionage shadow war to try to collect intelligence on leadership thinking and military capabilities.
content: As China’s spy balloon drifted across the continental United States in February, American intelligence agencies learned that President Xi Jinping of China had become enraged with senior Chinese military generals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Kieran Dodds
title: The Game of Their Lives
description: Every week, a group of former pros gathers for what may be the best pickup soccer game in the world. The appeal is a chance to engage with the sport on their terms.
content: As the players idled by the chain-link fence at the side of the field, taking great gulps of air and water and conducting an immediate autopsy of the game that had just finished, they focused their attention on three outstanding bones of contention. Instinctively, they separated into dedicated working groups to tackle each one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Finland’s President, No Stranger to Russia, Warns Europe About Complacency
description: President Biden has consulted Sauli Niinisto throughout Russia’s war against Ukraine. Europeans should not dismiss the risks of a wider war, he says.
content: The president of Finland, Sauli Niinisto, is the person considered most responsible for bringing his country into the NATO alliance — and Sweden, too, which is awaiting ratification — following the Russian invasion of Ukraine. President Biden has consulted him about Russia and its president, Vladimir V. Putin, whom Mr. Niinisto has met numerous times.
source.name: The New York Times
